channel.title: Pings... Don't post
channel.description:
If you don't have a firewall, you should definitely do this. If you run a webserver on that computer, try to do this anyways, if everything works fine when you bring it up, it will be good news!
This is a very easy tweak since you only have to change one little regestry entry.
Go to Start > Run > regedit > HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE > SYSTEM > CurrentControlSet > Services > Tcpip > Parameters > Double Click on EnableICMPRedirect and change its value to 0.
Bookmark this thread, and reboot your computer. Once finished rebooting, go to [url=http://scan.sygatetech.com/prequickscan.html]Sygate's Quick Scan[/url]. The scan should take about 30 seconds to 1 minute. Now go all the way to the bottom and Port ICMP should be closed.
If the port is still not closed, then the probing can't connect to your computer because you have a firewall or a proxy or something. [url=http://www.dslreports.com/scan]So then try this scan[/url].
If you have any problems at all such as not able to connect to the internet or have your computer as a webserver, just simply reverse this procedure. Go to the same entry and replace it with a 1.
~Ron
Edit: Changed title, and will not be posting on this thread. I'm getting too pissed off at... people .. like hellothere. So if you have an opinion, don't bother posting. Since an opinion is like an asshole... everyone has one, you're not special if you shoot it out. :)

item.title: Pings... Don't post
item.dc:creator: @hellothere hellothere
item.description:
@hellothere wrote:

sorry didnt see the question, but either way disabling pings is only half the battle, incomming pings will still fill up your connection unless you have your isp filter them upstream, which of course still congests the upstream router. There is no winning against lameness of a DOS.

Read full topic

item.title: Pings... Don't post
item.dc:creator: @Ron Ron
item.description:
@Ron wrote:

PaulT:

Ron, Ron, Ron.

Yes yes yes? What???

[quote=“hellothere, post:40, topic:3324”]Ron ron ron…
Hackers dont try to overrun buffers all the time. Buffer overflow vulnerabilities are put into software by the programmers who make mistakes. This is more time than I wanted to spend on this but I figure I should since you obviously have a false sense of security, or rather a false confidence in your none existent security knowledge.

Now, a buffer overflow goes something like this:

lameness.c

int main(int argc, char * argv[])
{
char buff[255];
strcpy(buff, argv[1]);
return 0;
}
./lameness perl -e 'print "A" x 400';
Segmentation fault.

Now as you can probably not tell, the programmer(in this case me) its not checking the size of argv before trying to put it into buff, therefore if a string longer than 254 chars is entered buff will be overflown, this if done correctly can lead to the overwritting of the return address which is on the stack. Resulting in arbitrary code execution.

Again, “Hacking Exposed” might not be a reliable source of security knowledge. Try reading a decent paper like aleph1 “Smashing the stack for fun and profit”.

Note: The program above could have some mistake since I cant be bothered to compile it.

Also nobody “told” me about security, only through experimentation can you be sure that your version of reality coincides with reality itself.

And finally, the article which you posted shows no relation between a DDOS and a buffer overflow(as expected), the only note of buffer overflows being mentioned is:
“It has been observed that the variants use one of the following vulnerabilities to propagate. It is essential to remediate these vulnerabilities to disable future infections.”
“3) The Workstation service buffer overrun vulnerability (described in Microsoft Security Bulletin MS03-049) using TCP port 445. Windows XP users are protected against this vulnerability if Microsoft Security Bulletin MS03-043 has been applied. Windows 2000 users must apply MS03-049.”
Which, of course, means that the bot uses a vulnerability in some software in order to gain control of the host from which it then proceeds to join in DDOS attacks. I’m affraid reading comprehension is fundamental on the security bussiness.[/quote]
Well I don’t care. Believe me or not, do what you think is best, I don’t care. I hate getting into arguments over the net. Impossible to win, just a waste of time and agravation. I don’t have the patience for it anymore… I’m too old… 16 lol.

Read full topic

item.title: Pings... Don't post
item.dc:creator: @hellothere hellothere
item.description:
@hellothere wrote:

Ron ron ron…
Hackers dont try to overrun buffers all the time. Buffer overflow vulnerabilities are put into software by the programmers who make mistakes. This is more time than I wanted to spend on this but I figure I should since you obviously have a false sense of security, or rather a false confidence in your none existent security knowledge.

Now, a buffer overflow goes something like this:

lameness.c

int main(int argc, char * argv[])
{
char buff[255];
strcpy(buff, argv[1]);
return 0;
}
./lameness perl -e 'print "A" x 400';
Segmentation fault.

Now as you can probably not tell, the programmer(in this case me) its not checking the size of argv before trying to put it into buff, therefore if a string longer than 254 chars is entered buff will be overflown, this if done correctly can lead to the overwritting of the return address which is on the stack. Resulting in arbitrary code execution.

Again, “Hacking Exposed” might not be a reliable source of security knowledge. Try reading a decent paper like aleph1 “Smashing the stack for fun and profit”.

Note: The program above could have some mistake since I cant be bothered to compile it.

Also nobody “told” me about security, only through experimentation can you be sure that your version of reality coincides with reality itself.

And finally, the article which you posted shows no relation between a DDOS and a buffer overflow(as expected), the only note of buffer overflows being mentioned is:
“It has been observed that the variants use one of the following vulnerabilities to propagate. It is essential to remediate these vulnerabilities to disable future infections.”
“3) The Workstation service buffer overrun vulnerability (described in Microsoft Security Bulletin MS03-049) using TCP port 445. Windows XP users are protected against this vulnerability if Microsoft Security Bulletin MS03-043 has been applied. Windows 2000 users must apply MS03-049.”
Which, of course, means that the bot uses a vulnerability in some software in order to gain control of the host from which it then proceeds to join in DDOS attacks. I’m affraid reading comprehension is fundamental on the security bussiness.

item.title: Pings... Don't post
item.dc:creator: @Ron Ron
item.description:
@Ron wrote:

HELLO THERE? ARE YOU THERE?

Hackers try to overrun the buffer all the time! It’s one of the major friggen exploits in Microsoft. I hope you’re not one of those people who believe in, “You can’t get hacked unless you click on a bad link” BULLSHIT. There doesn’t have to be a vulnerability in the firewall, the firewall may try to keep a flood control, but it can’t protect it completely. Exactly why people get hacked everyday even if they have firewalls. Do you remember when Cisco got hacked? Do you remember when Microsfoft Corporation got hacked?

DDOS has a role in overrunning the buffer. Read about it, you’ll see.
Here is the article.

I don’t know where you learned your security information man, but whoever told you, is dumb or told you several years ago. Get up to date. I don’t know why you’re trying to argue with me. If you don’t like what I’m saying, go do something else.

Read full topic

item.title: Pings... Don't post
item.dc:creator: @hellothere hellothere
item.description:
@hellothere wrote:

Well seeing as buffer overflows have nothing to do with this type of “attack” you lost me back there. And buffer overflows are nothing special to bypass firewall rules, unless of course there is such vulnerability on the firewall itself at which point you dont need to bypass it, since you can run arbitrary code as that user.

Read full topic

item.title: Pings... Don't post
item.dc:creator: @hellothere hellothere
item.description:
@hellothere wrote:

[quote=“Ron, post:27, topic:3324”]ICMP Vulnerabilties

smart ass[/quote]

Ron, the bugtraq link posted is apparently linux related. If you notice www.kerneltrap.org is a kernel development website, ie tottally unrelated to windows. Also someone knowing your online status is not a big deal. And finally, decent firewall rules allow for both maintenance of service and decent protection from these so called attacks which ammount to nothing more than simple denial of service. If you are really worried about security you should be worrying why your Internet Explorer is bound into the windows kernel or maybe things you cant really control such as inherent tcp vulnerabilities like timming attacks.

Read full topic

item.title: Pings... Don't post
item.dc:creator: @Ron Ron
item.description:
@Ron wrote:

When your computer allows pings to your IP address, hackers can see your online status. If you are being attacked, the hacker can use the speed and packet loss percentage to monitor the attack. When you are stealthed or using a proxy, the hacker can only get the IP address of the proxy server. The proxy server provider should have a good firewall in place to block the attack and not show your online status.

Read full topic
